sentences.sentence: Hatred directed at Jewish-Canadians following the Oct. 7 Hamas atrocities and Israel's responding invasion of Gaza rivals the antisemitism experienced by Jewish immigrants to Canada early in the 20th century.

The Jewish community, ordinarily sensitive to threats, was nevertheless shocked by both the scale of the hatred and the realization that it was fomented by an unlikely source - universities.Much of this antisemitism is manufactured by radical faculty members, who view the university more as an instrument of change than a liberal institution that values scholarship, freedom of thought and the ability to entertain competing ideas.In some academic disciplines, and for specific issues, such as the Israel-Palestine conflict, serious scholarship is abandoned by radical professors who are willing to subordinate liberal values to the service of a political cause.
The result is ideology in the guise of scholarship that is transmitted as "knowledge" to achieve political goals.

Consequently, the "knowledge" that is produced lacks an epistemological basis but has a veneer of veracity, and an academic community develops to perpetuate it.To champion Palestinian rights, progressives formulated an ideology that vilifies Israel as a "colonizing apartheid state," which is absurd on its face.

In fact, Jews are indigenous to the land, and Arab-Israelis are citizens with equal rights, who occupy positions as members of parliament, judges of the high court, lawyers, doctors and professors.While the situation on the West Bank is gravely problematic, Palestinians are as much (if not more) to blame for the current situation, due to their refusal to negotiate an end to the conflict.

Gaza may be described as an "open air prison," but that is entirely due to Hamas, an Iranian proxy whose goal of destroying Israel makes the Israeli-Egyptian blockade necessary.The campus campaign for Palestinians, cloaked in the garb of human rights, has fed generations of students with misinformation while illiberally prohibiting the expression of Israeli perspectives, which trigger threats and intimidation from student mobs, often led by or including faculty members.

University administrators, having long failed to permit the expression of diverse viewpoints, now require a massive police presence to do so.The result is that leftist antisemitism is now entrenched in our universities and poses a greater threat than the far-right.
What extremists on the left appear to share with those on the right is a contempt for the law.

Lesley Wood, a York University sociology professor, and other York employees, have been charged with hate-motivated mischief for allegedly defacing an Indigo bookstore because it was founded by a Jew who identifies with Israel.Alarmingly, this illiberalism has infected Canadian law schools, which are tasked with training new lawyers and have the fundamental mission of transmitting liberal values consistent with the rule of law.

Law faculties cannot seem to muster dissenting voices when colleagues or students make outrageous public statements approving of terrorism.Following Hamas's slaughter of 1,200 Israelis, Heidi Matthews, an Osgoode Hall Law School professor, justified the atrocity as a "resistance," tweeting: "A lot of obfuscation going on about what the right of resistance looks like in brutally asymmetric contexts."

Not a single faculty member publicly objected.At the University of Ottawa, instructors of a course on prison law reform thought nothing of using the context of Hamas's massacre as an occasion to indoctrinate students about Israel being an "apartheid state," a topic irrelevant to the course.

And at Toronto Metropolitan University, 74 people, mostly law students, signed a statement saying that "all forms of Palestinian resistance" are acceptable.Antisemitism also comes out of post-colonialism departments, which view society as a conflict between settlers of European descent (or anyone who is white) and indigenous people.
Jews, who had little to do with settling Canada, are nevertheless deemed to be colonizers for successfully integrating into society by achieving representation in many aspects of Canadian life.

Israeli Jews, whose ancestors were native to the Land of Israel, are also cast aside as colonizers.This labelling of Canadian Jews as "colonizers" and framing their support for Israel as somehow being complicit with "apartheid" or "genocide" produces fertile soil for antisemitism.

Perhaps this explains why educational campaigns to promote equity, diversity and inclusion do not address hatred of Jews, who suffer the highest per capita rate of hate crimes in North America.There is a gaping disjuncture between an academic culture that promotes respectful pronoun use and sensitivity to micro-aggressions, while at the same time encouraging the vilification of Jews and the Jewish state.The antagonism toward Jews is the canary in the coal mine of a declining liberal democracy that's under attack both from the populist right and the radical left.

The threat posed by the latter has been dangerously underestimated.Nations often err by pointing their guns in the direction of the last great threat, and while the Trump phenomenon continues to bedevil many Americans, and the far-right remains a menace, the bigger concern in both Canada and the United States is the challenge to liberal institutions by academic radicals and the moderates who, preferring the path of least resistance, remain silent.National PostHoward Gerson is a Toronto lawyer and Harold Waller is professor emeritus of political science at McGill University.Chris Selley: Universities could at least try countering antisemitism.

They might even see results(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/universities-could-at-least-try-countering-antisemitism)Jonathan Kay: Give me the Freedom Convoy over antisemitic campus lunatics any day(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/jonathan-kay-give-me-the-freedom-convoy-over-antisemitic-campus-lunatics-any-day) !
